The **Cape to Cairo Railway** is an uncompleted project to cross Africa from
south to north by [rail](/wiki/Rail_transport "Rail transport"). This plan was
initiated at the end of the 19th century, during the time of Western colonial
rule, largely under the vision of [Cecil Rhodes](/wiki/Cecil_Rhodes "Cecil
Rhodes"), in the attempt to connect adjacent African possessions of the
[British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") through a continuous
line from [Cape Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape Town"), [South
Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") to [Cairo](/wiki/Cairo "Cairo"),
[Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt"). While most sections of the Cape to Cairo railway
are in operation, a major part is missing between northern [Sudan](/wiki/Sudan
"Sudan") and [Uganda](/wiki/Uganda "Uganda").[1]

##
Construction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_to_Cairo_Railway&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Construction")]

Imperialist and entrepreneur [Cecil Rhodes](/wiki/Cecil_Rhodes "Cecil Rhodes")
was instrumental in securing the southern states of the continent for the
[British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") and envisioned a
continuous "red line" of British dominions from north to south. A railway
would be a critical element in this scheme to unify the possessions,
facilitate governance, enable the military to move quickly to hot spots or
conduct war, help settlement and enable intra- and extra-continental goods
trade. The construction of this project presented a major technological
challenge.

France had a somewhat rival strategy in the late 1890s to link its western and
eastern African colonies, namely [Senegal](/wiki/Senegal "Senegal") to
[Djibouti](/wiki/Djibouti "Djibouti"). [Southern Sudan](/wiki/Southern_Sudan
"Southern Sudan") and [Ethiopia](/wiki/Ethiopia "Ethiopia") were in the way,
but France sent expeditions in 1897 to establish a protectorate in southern
Sudan and to find a route across Ethiopia. The scheme foundered when a British
flotilla on the [River Nile](/wiki/River_Nile "River Nile") confronted the
French expedition at the point of intersection between the French and British
routes, leading to the [Fashoda Incident](/wiki/Fashoda_Incident "Fashoda
Incident") and eventual French retreat.

The [Portuguese](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal") considered an Angola to Mozambique
railway to link west with east and produced the "[Pink Map](/wiki/Pink_Map
"Pink Map")" representing their claims to sovereignty in Africa (to link
[Angola](/wiki/Portuguese_Angola "Portuguese Angola") and
[Mozambique](/wiki/Portuguese_Mozambique "Portuguese Mozambique")).

Opposition to British rule in South Africa was settled after the
[First](/wiki/First_Boer_War "First Boer War") and
[Second](/wiki/Second_Boer_War "Second Boer War") Boer Wars (ended 1902 but
only incorporating its two states into a union Republic in 1910).

## Missed
completion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_to_Cairo_Railway&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Missed completion")]

British interests had to overcome obstacles of geography and climate, and the
competing imperial schemes of the French and Portuguese mentioned above and of
the Germans. In 1891, Germany secured the strategically critical territory of
[German East Africa](/wiki/German_East_Africa "German East Africa"), which
along with the mountainous rainforest of the [Belgian
Congo](/wiki/Belgian_Congo "Belgian Congo") precluded the building of a Cape-
to-Cairo railway.

In 1916 during [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") British and
British Indian soldiers won the [Tanganyika
Territory](/wiki/Tanganyika_Territory "Tanganyika Territory") from the Germans
and after the war the British continued to rule the territory, which was a
[League of Nations mandate](/wiki/League_of_Nations_mandate "League of Nations
mandate") from 1922. The continuous line of colonies was complete. The
[British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") possessed the
political power to complete the Cape to Cairo Railway, but economics,
including the [Great Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression") of
the 1930s, prevented its completion before [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II
"World War II").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] After World War II, the [decolonisation of
Africa](/wiki/Decolonisation_of_Africa "Decolonisation of Africa") and the
establishment of independent countries removed the colonial rationale for the
project and increased the project's difficulty, effectively ending the
project.

## Current
links[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_to_Cairo_Railway&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Current links")]

### Northern
section[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_to_Cairo_Railway&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Northern section")]

Egypt has a rail system that as early as 1854 connected
[Alexandria](/wiki/Alexandria "Alexandria") and [Cairo](/wiki/Cairo "Cairo"),
and that currently goes as far south as [Aswan](/wiki/Aswan "Aswan"). In Egypt
the railway is [1,435 mm](/wiki/Standard_gauge "Standard gauge") (4 ft 8 1⁄2
in) standard gauge. After a [ferry](/wiki/Train_ferry "Train ferry") link up
on the [Nile](/wiki/Nile "Nile"), the railway continues in [Sudan](/wiki/Sudan
"Sudan") from [Wadi Halfa](/wiki/Wadi_Halfa "Wadi Halfa") to
[Khartoum](/wiki/Khartoum "Khartoum") at the 1,067 mm (3 ft 6 in) [narrow
gauge](/wiki/Narrow_gauge "Narrow gauge"); see [Northern Africa Railroad
Development](/wiki/Northern_Africa_Railroad_Development "Northern Africa
Railroad Development"). This part of the system was started by [Lord
Kitchener](/wiki/Horatio_Kitchener,_1st_Earl_Kitchener "Horatio Kitchener, 1st
Earl Kitchener") in 1897 when he subjugated the [Mahdist](/wiki/Muhammad_Ahmad
"Muhammad Ahmad") uprising. Further railway links go south, the most southern
point being [Wau](/wiki/Wau,_Sudan "Wau, Sudan"). A large part of the Sudanese
railway network is currently in disrepair due to political turmoil.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Uganda
railway[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_to_Cairo_Railway&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Uganda railway")]

Main article: [Uganda Railway](/wiki/Uganda_Railway "Uganda Railway")

East Africa has a network of narrow gauge 1,000 mm (3 ft 3 3⁄8 in) railways
that historically grew from ports on the [Indian Ocean](/wiki/Indian_Ocean
"Indian Ocean") and went westward, built in parallel under British and German
colonial rule. The furthest string north was the [Uganda
Railway](/wiki/Uganda_Railway "Uganda Railway"). Eventually these networks
were linked, so that today there is a continuous rail connection between
[Kampala](/wiki/Kampala "Kampala"), [Uganda](/wiki/Uganda "Uganda"), on [Lake
Victoria](/wiki/Lake_Victoria "Lake Victoria") to the coastal cities of
[Mombasa](/wiki/Mombasa "Mombasa") in [Kenya](/wiki/Kenya "Kenya") and [Dar es
Salaam](/wiki/Dar_es_Salaam "Dar es Salaam") in [Tanzania](/wiki/Tanzania
"Tanzania"). Up to the break-up of the [East African
Community](/wiki/East_African_Community "East African Community") in 1977,
these companies operated as [East African
Railways](/wiki/East_African_Railways_and_Harbours_Corporation "East African
Railways and Harbours Corporation"), but operate today as different national
companies: the [Uganda Railways Corporation](/wiki/Uganda_Railways_Corporation
"Uganda Railways Corporation") Uganda railways corporation's assets were sold
over 13 years ago when government failed to run the corporation, as the cost
of running it was greater than the returns. Today, railway business in Uganda
is run by Rift Valley Railways of Kenya, the [Kenya Railways
Corporation](/wiki/Kenya_Railways_Corporation "Kenya Railways Corporation"),
and the [Tanzania Railways Corporation](/wiki/Tanzania_Railways_Corporation
"Tanzania Railways Corporation").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### TAZARA
link[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_to_Cairo_Railway&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: TAZARA link")]

Main article: [TAZARA Railway](/wiki/TAZARA_Railway "TAZARA Railway")

From Dar es Salaam, a 1,860 km link to [Kapiri Mposhi](/wiki/Kapiri_Mposhi
"Kapiri Mposhi") in [Zambia](/wiki/Zambia "Zambia") was completed after six
years by workers and with main funding by China in 1976. This Tanzania-Zambia-
Railway (TAZARA) was built to connect landlocked Zambia and its mineral wealth
to a port on the [Indian Ocean](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean"),
independent from port connections in South Africa, a frequent rival economic
competitor in the mining sectors or Mozambique, at that time Portuguese-
controlled territory. Not intended in the grand picture of the Cape to Cairo
Railway, the TAZARA fills a critical link. This connection is the 1,067 mm (3
ft 6 in) gauge of the [southern part of Africa](/wiki/Southern_Africa
"Southern Africa").

### Kidatu
connection[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_to_Cairo_Railway&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Kidatu connection")]

In 1998, a transshipment hub was built at [Kidatu](/wiki/Kidatu "Kidatu") in
southern [Tanzania](/wiki/Tanzania "Tanzania") to connect the [metre
gauge](/wiki/Metre_gauge "Metre gauge") [Central Line
(Tanzania)](/wiki/Central_Line_\(Tanzania\) "Central Line \(Tanzania\)") with
the [Cape gauge](/wiki/Cape_gauge "Cape gauge") [TAZARA](/wiki/TAZARA
"TAZARA") line. This also shortened the distance.

### Southern
section[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_to_Cairo_Railway&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Southern section")]

The southern section was completed during British rule before the First World
War and has an interconnecting system of national railways using the Cape-
gauge of 1,067 mm (3 ft 6 in). Construction started from [Cape
Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape Town") and went parallel to the [Great North
Road](/wiki/Great_North_Road_\(Africa\) "Great North Road \(Africa\)") to
[Kimberley](/wiki/Kimberley,_South_Africa "Kimberley, South Africa"), through
a part of [Botswana](/wiki/Botswana "Botswana") to [Bulawayo](/wiki/Bulawayo
"Bulawayo"). From this junction the link proceeds further north, today
operated by the [National Railways of
Zimbabwe](/wiki/National_Railways_of_Zimbabwe "National Railways of
Zimbabwe"), to the [Zambezi](/wiki/Zambezi "Zambezi") crossing. The [Victoria
Falls Bridge](/wiki/Victoria_Falls_Bridge "Victoria Falls Bridge") was
completed in 1905. The connection is picked up by [Zambia
Railways](/wiki/Zambia_Railways "Zambia Railways") and continues to [Kapiri
Mposhi](/wiki/Kapiri_Mposhi "Kapiri Mposhi") which is the transition point to
the TAZARA link to Tanzania.

## Road[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_to_Cairo_Railway&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Road")]

The [Court Treatt expedition](/wiki/Court_Treatt_expedition "Court Treatt
expedition"), an attempt to travel from Cape to Cairo by road, was made in
1924 using two cars.[2]

The [Cape to Cairo Road](/wiki/Cape_to_Cairo_Road "Cape to Cairo Road") was
planned to roughly connect the same countries. That plan was updated with the
Cairo–Cape Town Highway plan, large sections of which are paved and passable.
